pli-tv-bu-vb-sk45:1.3.1: According to Sp.2.621 this means repeatedly breaking pieces off a ball of food. The word avacchedaka, is further explained at Vin-vn-ṭ.1920 as chinditvā, “having broken off”. This, it seems, can only refer to breaking off pieces, not to biting. Each ball of food was a single a mouthful, consisting of rice with suitable curry.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk45:1.11: According to Sp.2.615 khajjaka refers to all fresh foods: Ettha mūlakhādanīyādi sabbaṁ gahetabbaṁ, “Here the fresh foods which are roots, etc. may all be taken.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk45:1.12: Phalāphale. See PED, s.v. ā⁴.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk45:1.13: Uttaribhaṅga. According to Vin-vn-ṭ.1907 this is just another word for byañjana: uttaribhaṅgaṁ nāma byañjanaṁ. Byañjana seems to refer to curries apart from the standard bean-curries, which are called sūpa.
